docs.lead_paragraph: TALES of desperation involving people addicted to gambling are nothing new; stories of broken homes and beleaguered bank accounts have inspired more than one movie maker. But now state-run lotteries are feeling the heat. With their new Quick Draw keno games in bars and delis, the states are turning ordinary people who never get near a casino into the addicted, Money magazine says in its May issue. Lotteries, often chastised as preying on the poor, don't take a spare dollar a week just from those who can least spare it. They also take money from young professionals who might do better by putting it in their 401(k) plans or elsewhere.

headline.main: Throwing Some Cold Water on Lottery Fever

docs.lead_paragraph: CLORINDA MORELLI turned 106 last week, celebrating the occasion quietly with her 80-year-old daughter, friends at the nursing home where she resides and, if not as many candles on the cake as years, then at least memories of a life well lived. The secret to her longevity: "Hard work and a happy-go-lucky attitude," said Mrs. Morelli, who traveled by ship from Milan, Italy, to America when she was 19 to marry her boyfriend, Luigi. Later she worked in a dress factory, raised three children and only moved to the county-run nursing home, the Ruth Taylor Geriatric and Rehabilitation Institute in Valhalla, when her daughter grew too old to care for her.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT are the most contentious workplace issues of the 1990's? Drug testing and race discrimination would be among the correct answers, but another issue has also become a surprising battleground: infertility. Consider the case of Charline Pacourek. After years of undergoing treatment for infertility, Ms. Pacourek was dismissed from her job with Inland Steel Industries in 1993. The company cited poor performance and frequent absences. She said the dismissal was because of her treatments and she sued, contending that her civil rights had been violated.

headline.main: Infertility Is a New Focus of Workplace Lawsuits

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An April 14 news article says many experts on insurance regard medical savings accounts, which would allow people to put pretax dollars aside to pay insurance deductibles, as "worth trying on only a small scale."

docs.lead_paragraph: As a relatively modest piece of health insurance legislation moves through Congress, it seems to be producing an unexpected turnabout among people who lived through the agonizing debate over the same issue in the first two years of the Clinton Administration. In 1993 and 1994, people who supported President Clinton's ambitious plan to guarantee health insurance for every American said that anything less than a complete overhaul of the health care system might cause more problems than it solved.

headline.main: Health Legislation: Gradualism Wins the Day, for Now, but DoubtsPersist

docs.lead_paragraph: Injecting its voice into the debate over economic insecurity, a lobbying group representing the nation's manufacturers issued an analysis today that it said rebutted "the conventional wisdom that wage stagnation and job loss represent reality for American workers." The National Association of Manufacturers said in its report that there were valid reasons why workers might feel uneasy about the future, reciting what has now become a familiar list to employees of almost any company: global competition, the fast pace of technological change, demands on the labor force to continually upgrade its skills and the bigger bite taken out of paychecks by taxes.

headline.main: Group Asserts U.S. Workers Are Better Off Than Thought

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate cleared the way tonight for passage of legislation that would make health insurance more accessible, narrowly defeating an amendment by Senator Bob Dole that opponents charged would have killed the bill. Before adjourning close to midnight, the Senate disposed of all other amendments to the measure and scheduled a vote on final passage, which is assured, for Tuesday.

headline.main: Senate Defeats Dole Revision To Health Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft Profit Rises 42%, Topping Analysts' Forecasts Microsoft reported a 42 percent earnings rise to $562 million, beating analyst estimates and belying reports of a slump in the personal computer industry.
